title.narrative: Provision of integrated multi-sectoral and lifesaving services to drought/AWD and conflict affected communities in Wanlaweyn, Qoryoley and Kurtunwarey districts of Lower Shabelle

description.narrative: The project intends to provide access to an integrated package of emergency lifesaving services including health, nutrition and WASH to 59,600 IDPs and host community (34,740 IDPs, 23,836 people in host) in Wanlaweyn, Qoryoley and Kurtunwarey districts of Lower Shabelle in South Central Somalia. The proposed intervention will will be delivered through integrated response teams-1 per district to provide services to the vulnerable including those in hard to reach villages and pastrolists. Health/Nutrition: For the target population, access to basic health and nutrition services is limited, increasing morbidity and mortality from treatable conditions. Health challenges/needs are mostly profound among the most vulnerable groups pregnant and lactating women and children under five years. According to the FSNAU, the GAM rates in this IDPs are at 16.1%, SAM rate of 4.1% and Crude death rate of 0.79, Under five mortality rate of 1.77 while morbidity is at 44.1% . Immunization coverage is low among these groups. In response to this, WARDI will enhance service delivery through setting up 6 integrated mobile outreach teams. The integrated teams will provide integrated maternal, neonatal and child health and nutrition services. Key services to be availed will include immunization, management of childhood illnesses, detection and management/referral of severe acute malnutrition and provision of focused antenatal and postnatal care and referral for skilled delivery. Critical component to the intervention will be aggressive community education and sensitization on critically important issues of infant young child feeding, prevention and treatment of diarrhoea, hygiene promotion and health facility delivery. In total 59,600 persons will access high quality free of charge health and nutrition services. WASH: At least 15,700 (3749 men, 4636 women, 3121 boys and 3794 girls) drought and AWD affected IDPs and host communities have emergency and sustainable access to safe water through water voucher for 60 days rehabilitation of 1 strategic borehole in Qoryoley town, rehabilitation of 3 shallow wells in Wanlaweyn district and capacity building of WASH committees, well operators and Community Committees while environmental sanitation is improved through construction of 58 gender sensitive, flood proof latrines (28 for male and 30 for female), and conducting hygiene promotion awareness campaigns including distribution of 1000 hygiene promotion kits in our three target districts.
